description: From French épidémique, from épidémie, from Medieval Latin epidēmia, reanalysis of plural Late Latin epidēmia, from Ancient Greek ἐπιδήμιος (epidḗmios), from ἐπί (epí, “upon”) + δῆμος (dêmos, “people”). Surface analysis epi- (“on”) +‎ demic (“of the people”).

adjectives.description: epidemic (comparative more epidemic, superlative most epidemic)

entries.meaning: Like or having to do with an epidemic; widespread.
examples: Synonyms: common, ubiquitous; see also Thesaurus:widespread
Epidemic hysteria occurred upon the incumbent’s reelection.

entries.meaning: A widespread disease that affects many individuals in a population.
(epidemiology) An occurrence of a disease or disorder in a population at a frequency higher than that expected in a given time period; an episode of outbreak and subsequent high prevalence.
(figurative) The spreading of an idea or belief amongst a population.
